title: Projects
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

View the tutorial for this template (+ download link)

title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.



















View the tutorial for this template (+ download link)

title: Hi, I’m Dave
text:
Hi, I’m Dave
I’m a Research Fellow and PhD Candidate with the Data Matters group at Monash University. I work on a range of projects that aim to help policymakers make evidence-informed decisions. This involves creating and synthesising high-quality evidence on the effectiveness, implementation and economic impact of complex interventions in social welfare and human services. I focus on applying causal inference methods to generate evidence and (increasingly, Bayesian) meta-analytic methods, to synthesise it.

title: Projects
text:
Here you’ll find information about some of the research projects I’ve worked on. I try to make all my work as open as possible, so you’ll find links to publications, registrations and code repositories where available. If you have any questions about any of these projects, please don’t hesitate to get in touch.

title: What works for care leavers?

title: What works for care leavers?
text:
Preregistration
Taylor, D., Shlonksy, A., Lewis, J., Chakraborty, S., Mendes, P., Macdonald, G., Williams. K. (2020) The effectiveness of policies, programs or interventions to improve health and psychosocial outcomes for young people leaving the out of home care system: a systematic review [Preregistration]. PROSPERO. CRD42020146999 https://www.crd.york.ac.uk/prospero/display_record.php?ID=CRD42020146999

title: What works for care leavers?
text:
This systematic review emerged from my work at the Centre for Evidence and Implementation, where I was working on an impact evaluation of a program to support young people leaving out-of-home care. This sparked my interest in understanding the broader evidence base on policies and programs to support care leavers, and both projects ultimately became central to my PhD research.
The project evolved over several years. We initially conducted our search in 2020, producing a technical report for What Works for Children’s Social Care. When we updated the search in 2022, it served two purposes: ensuring our published review reflected the most recent evidence, and forming the basis for a separate review examining mental health services for care leavers.
We limited our inclusion criteria to studies with valid counterfactuals, including both randomized controlled trials and observational studies with comparison groups formed through matching or other statistical approaches that could plausibly control for selection into treatment. This yielded 16 studies, all but one of which was from the United States.
We found 16 studies examining a range of transition support programs and extended care policies. Twenty small meta-analyses were undertaken encompassing ILPs and C&PSP, with two showing results that favored the intervention with certainty. The level of confidence in each meta-analysis was considered very low. A significant risk of bias was identified in each of the included studies. While some interventions showed promise, particularly extended care, the scope and strength of included evidence is insufficient to recommend any included approach.
All materials from this project are openly available, including our protocol, pre-registration, technical reports, and supplementary materials. The GitHub repository contains all analysis code and data.



This project was funded by the What Works for Children’s Social Care.



This review was a collaboration between researchers from the Centre for Evidence and Implementation (who employed me at the time), Monash University and Bristol University and practitioners from The Fostering Network.

title: What works for care leavers?
text: This project was funded by the What Works for Children’s Social Care.
